If you have 4-5 hours, then it really deserves to pay a visit. Firstly the museum itself is great, secondly it exhibits a pretty comprehensive collection that starts from Paleolithic Era to Joseon Dinasty. If you want to know more about Korea's history, then it's a must!
Visit on rainy day, interesting facts and items about Koreas' history. Helps a lot to know Koreas' history beforehand.

Museum had lots of artifacts of the history of Korea, not so much with paintings but with stone and gold work as well as some jewels.  Depending on your interest can spend an hour to several hours.  Grounds are spread out and can find plenty of places to sit and enjoy the garden areas.

High class Museum. Very modern design, easy navigation through the various rooms and topics, large enough not to be crowded, concise explanations (in English too), free (yes!) ... and fantastic items on show. It was a pleasure all the way visiting this Museum. Note: If you just want to walk through, only stopping briefly in front a few spectacular pieces, I guess about 1.5 hrs are necessary. A more quiet visit may need about twice as much. I'd advise at least 2 hrs and be selective as there are very diverse topics exposed that are not likely to be of interest for everybody.

Lovely building in a gorgeous, peaceful setting. Art and history are displayed thoughtfully throughout the museum....open and inviting. Items on display often took ones breath away ... stunning! I took a tour with a museum volunteer (in English) which was chock full of facts about Korea and its history.

THE NATIONAL MUSEUM OF KOREA….ONE OF ASIA’S GREAT MUSEUMSThis is a truly amazing museum, set up in  a very large functional  building of contemporary design. Its exhibits are arranged in various period galleries – covering pre-history and ancient history of Korea, medieval and early modern history, calligraphy and painting, Asian art, as well as Korean  sculpture and arts. The Pre-history and Ancient History Gallery starts with the Paleolithic and Neolithic Periods, and covers the ascent of various Korean kingdoms, up to the Balhae kingdom. Among the exhibits are ancient farm implements, clay pottery of considerable geometrical accuracy, a range of weapons including steel swords, daggers, spearheads, arrowheads, and axes.  There is a beautifully-carved stone dagger, as well as stone tools, wood implements and the like from the Bronze Age. Among other exhibits of that period are a milling stone to grind acorn, and an early example of a dugout canoe. Korea’s Unified Silla Period is represented by a very ornamental gold crown of the royalty of that period. Its exquisite design and the high quality of workmanship would have done credit to a more contemporary product. There is also a range of jewellery, including necklaces and earrings  that had once graced the queens and princesses of that era. Of particular interest are gold, silver, bronze and iron vessels recovered from Silla Dynasty tombs.  A particularly rich haul has been from the tomb of King Huryeong of the Baekje period. This section of the museum has well over 7,500  carefully-selected artifacts of exceptional quality. The Medieval and Early Modern History Gallery has artifacts dating back to the Goryeo and Joseon dynasties. There is a very interesting section on Korea’s  Hangeul alphabet, and the metal printing types to print documents in that language. In that respect, Korean culture had achieved considerable precedence over Europe. The exhibits include several ancient documents in Hangeul. The Dharani Sutra woodblock printing technique of an earlier age, is said to date back to rhe eighth century, and is claimed to be “the oldest existing woodblock printed scripture in the world”. All credit to Korean culture.A section on the Joseon period showcases massive wooden furniture. Interestingly, they had separate furniture for men and for women, in that day and age. The section on Asian art has the  finest artifacts from India and Southeast Asia, Central  Asia. China and Japan. Among the high-quality  religious statues from India is  an exceptional one of God Siva and his consort Parvati.  In the Chinese section are a series of paintings laid out side by side. A closer look, however,  shows the water flowing in the rivulet across all five paintings. Boats ply on the water, while a little bird flies across the  paintings. These are very cleverly made movies. It is utterly brilliant.There is an awesome collection of Chinese porcelain obtained  from the Sinan shipwreck. The ship was carrying exquisite pottery from China  for use by Japanese temples, when it was wrecked.The section on porcelainware must be the envy of most other museums in the world. There is Buncheongware, celadon, as well as white porcelain. Particularly stunning is a celadon Ewer featuring a mythical creature with the body of a fish and the head of a dragon. This section also has audio-visual presentations  on quality porcelain craftsmanship.Equally fascinating is the section on Buddhist art and sculpture. Buddhism came to  Korea during the Three Kingdoms period. Some of the guilded metal statues of Buddha are of exceptional intricacy.  The Pensive Bodhisattvas are regarded by Koreans as “national treasures”, and are products of exceptional craftsmanship.  A large portrait of Buddha stretches from the floor to the ceiling. That section also has Buddhist metalware, Buncheongware and white porcelain.Among the most amazing exhibits in the museum is a ten-storey pagoda from the Gyeongcheonsa Temple site. It stretches almost from the ground floor to the roof of the museum, and is intricately carved from graniteDigital and audio guides are available on rental. These are in Korean, English, Chinese and Japanese. There are also programmes for visitors of all ages, from children onwards. There is a children’s museum that offers educational programmes for them. A library of reference works, museum shops that sell cultural products, restaurants, cafes, an 805-seat theatre for cultural programmes, free loan of strollers and wheel chairs for those who need them, as well as toilets, are among the facilities on offer. The museum’s permanent collections are  free for visitors, while the special exhibitions are charged admission. Parking for visitors’ cars is also charged. The museum is closed on Mondays, 1 January and on all holidays. The visit was an emotionally rewarding experience. Hormuz P. Mama

Bring your walking shoes and thinking caps because there's a lot to walk and see here in Ichon dong.  They have exhibits on every period of Korean history from the Gogoryeo to the waning days of Joseon.  A very great rainy day activity as well.  The grounds are popular for people taking family photos as well.

The National Museum of Korea is huge. The exhibition is very interesting but you might get bored after a few hours spent in the museum. I would suggest to do the different exhibition in different days as the museum is free.
Travelled to the museum on a Sunday morning by taxi. The Museum has English notes on most of the items. The. Artefacts are very interesting and the knowledge Gai ed most rewarding.

It is quite a walk from the nearby Ichon metro station. The museum is really too large for just one visit, so better take a leaflet and choose the items you want to see. The museum spans all of Koean history, from the Paleolithic onwards. I particularly liked the Buddhas on the third floor. Access is free. English explanations are rather limited. There are different museum shops, on on each floor, the main one is on the first floor.  The is a nearby the National Hangeul Museum. Could not visit that one though.

National Museum of Korea is a good place to visit if you are a visitor like me who spent a fortnight therel; the admission is for free and it holds exhibits from all over Asia and collections from private donors.
The museum is really huge and pretty. For people interested in history, this place is a mandatory point to visit. There are explanations in Korean and in English and there are tours available.
Huge collection of artifacts from the past. You can easily spend many hours in the National Museum of Korea.

The museum's architecture and gardens alone are worth the visit. Allow for at least 2 hours to see the Joseon period exhibits. Not worth renting an audio guide, since almost all of the exhibits have English explanations. This destination is on the Seoul City Tour bus Day Course route.

a bit of a distance from other sites. Also a bit of a hike from the station, even though station is meant for museum. Simply beautiful grounds and really well done attraction. A place you should visit while in Seoul.

There is loads to see in this museum, so much that I actually decided to take a full afternoon to see only the permanent exhibits session. The museum is easily accessible by subway. The permanent exhibit is full of interesting artefacts. The admission to the permanent exhibit is free of charge and there are audio guides available for a reasonable price. Definitely an amazing visit while in Seoul!

This is a great place to visit and should definiltely be included in any visitor's itinerary. The coolest thing is the exact replica of the Korean president's desk where you can get a photo of yourself there. There are tons of other exhibits there so allow time to see everything.

It has all Korean history. Lots of National Treasure. But entrance is free as of Nov 1st, 2015. The entrance should be at least 10USD. If you are interested in Korean buddhism, history from prehistoric era, this place will be perfect. You will need one hole day. At least half day. :)

It's rare to be impressed by the exposition of Stone Age objects and it is only first hall of this collection of historical miracles. The creators of the exposition prove that all the objects here are honorable treasures. They prove that they love the history and want the visitors to be involved in this exciting journey through the time.Really worth be seen. It is even sad that it is free of charge.

Check this out. This place has many floors. A lot of stairs but there are escalators too. It aslo has a cool tea house. Try the chestnut drink. Also thus museum had a garden.My favorite floor was the bottom where there is a big budda.
Went here on a rainy day to kill time. Some interesting and educational exhibits. Bring along your passport as deposit for the audio guide which can be rented cheaply (think it was 1000 won).

Loved the museum, a very large building with tons of space, felt like the exhibitions were a bit exclusive, very clean and nice. Also visited temporary Buddhist exhibition near the museum which was awesome. Do recommend!

I spent about three hours here and saw all three floors.  Take metro line 4 in direction of Oido and get off the Ichon stop exit 2. There is an underground path that takes you directly to the museum. Once above ground the museum is right in front of you. It's free!  Plenty of seating throughout the visit so you can rest in between exhibits.

Free entry and very nice and relax area. The museum is vast but not very impressive. If you want to understand little bit more about Korea ancient history it's a good place to start but in the end you'll seen a lots of ceramic stuff. The most interesting part is the Buddhist part

If you are history buff like me and always tend to visit National Museums in every country you visit. This is exactly for you. A great journey though Korean history in this multilevel modern and beautifully designed building. I joined a group of travellers in the english tour which took us through the highlights of the Museum. The tour guide was very knowledgable and answered question of the group and very helpful. Try the tea in the Koren tea house on the top level which overlooks a nice garden and views Itaewon.

Ticks all the boxes you would expect from a national museum, with a huge variety of items and excellent signs that follow chronologically to give you a great look into the history of this fascinating country. The building itself is very modern and has an elegant setting. You can easily spend half a day in here.

This museum is a great way to learn about ancient Korea and how it has changed over the years. There are tours available for foreigners, although you can opt to have a listening device if your  tour is over for the day. It is a good way to spend a rainy day.

This museum is a "don't miss" on your itinerary. First, this modern building has a very interesting design. Of course, it's the exhibits that count. I spent most of my time in the extended gallery that displayed  artifacts from the paleolithic to bronze age. It was so clearly laid out and seeing the progression in man's skills and art over that period was fascinating. The best exhibit of its kind that I have ever seen. The explanations in English were very good, but it is still worth paying for the headphones as the explanations were more fulsome.

This is truly one of the great national museums of the world. It covers the entirety of Korean history, plus has exhibits from China, Japan, India, Central & Southeast Asia, a large gallery of donated items including an ancient Greek bronze helmet, a gallery of items retrieved from the Sinan Shipwreck, stone and porcelain galleries, and a gallery of metalwork and Buddhist sculpture. There is a park of large stone sculptures outside. The highlight of the museum is probably the four Silla gold crowns displayed in several different galleries. While it normally takes me almost a full day to photograph a Chinese provincial museum for my Chinese and World History website, I spent two full days photographing this museum. It is the single best historic attraction in Korea and one of the best in all Asia.

Museums are all too frequently set aside for rainy/crappy days but this is worthy of a visit, regardless of the weather.To access it, take the #4 line in the direction of Oido and get off at the Ichon stop.  Follow the signs underground for the museum and you will eventually exit the metro at the base of the museum grounds.For a museum dedicated to history, the building is ironically very futuristic and “art nouveau-ish”.  It is laid out over 3 floors, with each floor having a theme.  The first floor, which I found the most engaging, was dedicated to the history of man on the Korean peninsula, from the Paleolithic period through to the 2nd millennium.  It was amazing to see the slow, natural progression from the first, crude stone tools used tens of thousands of years ago all the way to the use of  highly decorative jewelry, pottery, weapons and such some one hundred twenty years ago.The other floors are dedicated to paintings, calligraphy and sculpture.  It’s really only the third floor which decidedly fans out from Korea to include a section of Asian art from the entire continent.The museum is free and closed on Monday.

The building and the park impressed me the most even if they have an impressive collections of various aspects of the history. Artifacts shown gives a good exposure to all of the Korean peninsula's history from the days humans first the feet on the ground to the present date. Well, at least until 1950s. A pity too many explanations of the artifacts shown where in Korean only. With more info in English I'm sure I would have appreciated it more.

I showed up for the 11 AM English guided tour.  There were about a dozen of us.  Our tour guide spoke English very well and was very passionate in his tour.  He started off with about a 15 minute overview of the Korean history going back thousands of years.I thought the most interesting portion of his lecture was his explanation of the Korean alphabet.  Obviously he only had enough time, 1 1/2 hours, to hit on the highlights of the museum.   The museum is enormous.  But his tour was excellent.  I would highly recommend.

My first impression was - WOW! What a huge place, SPACE! Have been living in HK for a year where space is premium, to see and be in this vast place, I was overwhelmed! And to be treated to a surprised open-air traditional concert was a welcome bonus. We quickly walked round one exhibition area (had to get back onto the tour bus). There was a food court where the price is reasonable and the food are delicious. I highly recommend visitors to visit this place.

I have always love visiting musuems overseas to learn more about the history of the country so this place gets a thumbs up fr me!!! Wished I had more time to spend here, will definitely return again when I am in Korea!

The museum is worth visiting alone for the building its in - its a very impressive, big modern building -  both from outside and inside. Visiting is free, and if you have any interest in the history, culture and buddishm in Korea, you should definitely come here.The only big dissapointement for me: I would have loved to get an audio guide. But I didnt have my passport with me, and you need it as a deposit. I offered to leave a money deposit (like I did at Gyeongbokgung), but that was not possible unfortunately. Too bad, as with commentaries you learn so much more about the exhibits.If you are there during lunch time, there is a food court to the west of the entrance. You can get tasty and cheap food there, and its full of locals. There are several stalls, but you order at the "main desk", pay there, get a beeper and then collect your food from the stall.
The museum is worth visiting. I lIked the architecture of the museum and the exhibitions too. I could have stayed a total day.

Lovely that the museum is free to visit! A lovely 3 level museum featuring very interesting artifacts. The whole trip took me more than 2 hours because I enjoyed reading everything that was written on the exhibits (descriptions are in English as well!).

This is a big museum. However I just visited the Korean season and the important life events. The life events were really illuminating. Thoroughly enjoyed the displays and the information. Gave me an insight into their life. I was restricted in time at the museum, I wish that I had had more time to enjoy it.

Of all the museums I've been to, I recall most having witnessed some masterpieces that ppl read about in books.  The piece are what defines a museum for me and in all honesty (I'm trying to say this as nicely as I can...) I wasn't impressed.  There were a few pieces that caught my fancy...some of the crowns and prints, but there were too many 'unimpressive' items on display. I stopped counting the number of plates they had on display at...50.  I was most impressed with the actual museum because it is so huge and elaborate. That one sitting Buddha was cool too because he had so much character.

This museum is free!! But they do have a lot of materials. Also, the explanation is really good, well-organized, and English friendly. You can check out the history of Korea briefly, and look around Korean Tradition, too.
this is big museum and inside gwanghamun palace. I am lucky as I visited here on 16 august - Korea celebrating independence day, so admission fee was also free.
This museum has great history and art. The main hall is free, and there is a great mix of written explanation, as well as media presentations.

Probably one of the most interactive museums I've been too in a while. A lot of the displays allowed you to pick things to listen to. They had a water feature/art feature in one of the rooms as well. It was a really pretty place to be, especially on a nice spring day. I would definitely recommend.

If you're wishing to know more about the history of Korea and see some beautiful artifacts I highly recommend a trip to this museum. Many proud Koreans have donated their collections of artifacts to this museum.

I highly recommend this museum, it is organized in a great way that takes you through the history of the Korean Land and it's people.  Very good exhibits with plenty of English descriptions and dialogue.  I went midweek and it was not at all crowded, I'm sure the weekends are much busier.  A must see for museum lovers while in Seoul.

the museum is epic, one of the largest in the world. the only thing that I found some what annoying was that I did not understand the full scope of the pieces on display. The english part has only the title while you can see the Korean section is saying way more.Other than it is a pretty cool place to visit especially if the weather is bad or your plans got cancelled or if you're broke since its free!

The National Museum of Korea is a shiny new building in beautifully landscaped grounds and is one of the greatest national museums you can visit anywhere. Its permanent exhibition is absolutely massive and covers just about everything to ever happen in Korea, from the invention of stone tools to the 1870s and the beginning of modernization. Each gallery has excellent English descriptions, but many of the artifacts are stunning and speak for themselves. The glorious Silla dynasty crown is by far the must-see item of the collection, although there are countless statues, pieces of jewelry, tools, household items and other treasures which bring the fascinating history of this country to life. As someone who is usually not interested in Asian history and art, I was pleasantly surprised by how interested I became during the many hours I spent here. The upper floors are dedicated to themed displays, such as Buddhist painting or items from Japan or Central Asia, but I chose not to spend much time there as the Korean history sections were overwhelming in their content and quality. The National Museum was undoubtedly a highlight of my trip to Seoul and I wholeheartedly recommend it to everyone!

Be warned it is closed on Mondays. The National Museum is free and has a lot of beautiful artwork and  artifacts. If you are interested in Korean culture I would definitley go here. If it is not raining I would take time to walk around the park in front of it. If you have time and are studying Korean, the hangul museum is really interesting. It has exhibits on the creation of the hangul characters.

The place is just off the Ichon train station.  There is an underground path from the station to the Museum entrance, so look for the signs.  The museum ground is huge.  From the outside it beats any of the palaces in grandeur and scale.  A huge lake is in front, and the back is the Namsan tower.  There are plenty of displays about Korean history.  There's even a nearby museum for the Korean language.  Inside are good cafes and restaurants.  So anyone can easily spend a whole day here, if you are ok with the peace and quiet.  I was there on a weekday.
A nice, spacious museum. Wonderful Celadon and other style pottery! The collection of ancient Asian pottery and artifacts recently recovered from a sunken ship is especially interesting.

Decided to go to the museum on the night it was open until 8pm. No other people to be seen ! For a free musuem, you can't go wrong. Lots of interesting things to see at your own pace. Great view of N Tower too.

The building is enormous and ugly and the collection on display is rather disappointing and small for such a huge space (perhaps 5 to 6 times larger than the British Museum but less that 10% of stuff displayed there). Too much space for so little stuff, unless of course you are info Korean history (there is a large section of the rest of Asia that does not follow any historical or geographical logic). It has a lovely collection of Korean ceramics. In fact, this is the only think I enjoyed. For other stuff of Korean royal history best to head to the Nationl Palace Museum, which is elegant, intimate and superb.

There are hour long tours of the highlights in English at 10, 11 and 1400 which give you a good orientation.  I bought the museum book which helped me to choose the top sights.  Don't forget to look at the the building itself and to walk around the grounds, there is a pagoda garden, a small stream and waterfall and lovely trees.

The place is HUGE. I arrived later than I planned and made it through maybe half in 2+ hours. It's free to go to the main exhibition hall, so I didn't lose anything. If I get a chance I may go back. Another reviewer called it boring, maybe it is. This is probably not for everyone, there's loads of artifacts from long ago, and there is a lot of Korean history that can be witnessed but if that's not something you're into skip this place.
incredible collection of pottery, porcelain--with galleries by era--plus beautiful building and grounds with a bell tower and gardens
The museum is large and there is a lot to see; you can learn about of Korean history.  The main exhibit hall is free.  Their gift shop has some nice made-in-Korea items.
Walk from tour bus to museum way too long for and old person.  By the time I reached the museum, which is fantastic, I was really too tired to enjoy it fully
Impressive building in lovely setting. Collection of Korean art is unsurpassed. Everything is described in English as well as Korean.

This museum is HUGE. I've been there three times, and I still haven't seen everything. There is a mixture of art and history exhibited permanently, which is free; and special exhibits that you have to pay to see. This is a nice place to get an introduction to Korean history and the style of art the Koreans have used throughout history. You could easily spend all day here and still not see everything they have to show you. The only think that sucks about this place is the location. Since the building is so massive, it has been build kind of far from restaurants and other attractions. However, there are some restaurants and a convenience store outside.

Located in a purpose-built stately building and surrounding grounds, this museum is one of the best national museums I have ever visited. It takes you through the entirety of Korean peninsular history in a stepped, gradual way, so one can digest the "whole picture and truly learn something about this fascinating part of the world and its peoples. The exhibits are superb, and the assets and history are treated as belonging to the whole peninsula, so one walks away thinking of just one united Korea. The museum shop has amazing items that are hard to walk away from and could leave your credit card maxed out! Most incredible, entry was free!! There is also a mini-food hall to rest your feet and sample some nice Korean cuisine.A must-do in Seoul, allow 3 - 4 hours.
the title already explains it :) you can learn everything about korea's history from prehistoric time here.

What I liked about the National Museum of Korea is that it didn't take up my entire day to explore and enjoy.  It also has a great food court/restaurant area to have lunch before moving on with your day.When I arrived I checked in with the English speaking guide who told me an English guided tour had just left.  Within seconds she got on the radio and asked security where the group was at that moment.  I was escorted over and joined the tour.  That was great and unexpected and I didn't waste a single minute of time.  The guide was also very knowledgeable and was happy to answer questions from the group I was with.The museum has a beautiful collection with a beautiful history.  I recommend taking a tour or picking up the audio self guided tour to make sure you don't miss a beat.The day I went also had a lot of school children in attendance which made it fun and very lively.

As other reviewers have mentioned, the museum is large in scope and covers a wide swath of Korean history. I spent half a day here, but definitely did not have the time to look at everything in depth. One could easily spend the entire day browsing artifacts from ancient to modern Korean history. As someone who admittedly was not as familiar with the history of Korea, I definitely got a better sense of the different dynasties and historical figures. I had just come from visiting Buddhist sites in India, so the large array of Buddhist statues was interesting to see how the styles differ between different regions. The grounds outside are also good for walking and have a few statues and birds flying about. Did I mention that it's also free?

Great museum and well worth the time.  You could spend a couple days in there if you have the patients.  English translations are pretty good.  Best and most comprehensive Korean museum I've seen yet.  Everything else is just redundant and incomplete.

This museum gives an insight of Korea's history. Anyone who visits this museum without any knowledge of Korea, will leave the museum with substantial knowledge of this lovely country. That's guaranteed!

Every time I visit Seoul, I squeeze in a trip to the National Museum. It's free so if nothing's changed, that's ok. It's a great space just to wander around. But the installations change regularly and so, it's always interesting. It's a great place to learn about Korean imperial history and more recently, it has been building the section that shows not only imperial Korea's connection to China but to the Silk Road as well. It also has free air conditioning in the summer and, so, if you are looking for somewhere to get some reprieve during the monsoon season, this is a great place to kill two birds with one stone. There is a cafeteria that gets really crowded, and a nice tea/coffee place on the 2nd or 3rd floor that serves a great green tea paht bing soo in the summer. Cooling and culture in one trip = time well spent.

Great place. They have a device that you can listen to in the language of your choice (voice guided tour?) It can detect where you are and it will play the recording for that exhibit or you can pick which one you want to hear.  The device was not free, I believe you had to rent it for 1000 KRW, around $1 US.  They had very nice exhibit and cool artifacts.

I went to the National Museum of Korea based on TripAdvisors reader recommendations. The first impression when you arrive at the museum is how large and modern the two buildings look. The museum site on a slight hill so you look up at it when you arrive. In front of and below the museum is a large "Mirror" pond which the museum bldgs reflect into. Surrounding the pond are large, open, granite covered patios, benches and a couple of small coffee shops.The museum is made up of two large complexes left and right with a bldg above and between them. When you walk up the impression is of a large picture frame with a photo of the hills behind the museum.Nice.I paid approximately $12 to see the Pompeii exhibit that is currently on loan. There are headsets for a self guided tour and an app that will also take you through both museum's exhibits. All of the signage was also translated into English.After the Pompeii exhibit I went into the main bldg housing the exhibits on Korean history.There was no entry fee into this building.All of the exhibits were well kept, signage was again in many languages including English. Notes:- It may be the time of year but both bldgs/ exhibits were fairly empty. It made for relaxed viewing.- The museum grounds are spotless. Not a piece of litter anywhere.- Since the museum sits on a little hill there are stairs but also ramps for easy access.- There elevators or stairs to get to the various levels of the exhibits.- There is a large gift shop in the museum. - Refreshments: A couple of coffee shops where the taxi/ buses drop you off and a couple inside the museum.- Plenty of restrooms, clean and easy to find.- There are also "nursing rooms" and "Special Needs" facilities.All in all an excellent experience, good exhibits. I have to compliment the Korean arts community/ Gov't. They seem to have taken into consideration everything to make the experience a pleasant one.
Take the time to stroll the gardens before spending time inside. The gardens are very neat, and inside the museum is huge and well laid out to explore.

lovely ultra modern museum over three floors.  It's a little noisy in the main halls but the exhibition rooms are very good.  You can take photos and the lighting is good. The museum shop is also well worth visiting.The wi if is fast and FREE.
Free Entry, huge and beautiful filled with tons of artifactsThe exhibits are definitely impressive and quite informative .
great knowledge of korean culture. But need to be more elaborate and cleaned. More artifacts and explanations in english is necessary for foreigners to be fed with informations

National Museum of Korea and Hangul Museum of Korea are situated in adjoining locations.Hangul Museum is about origins of Korean Alphabets  made by their King about 500 years BC. well explained, showing its ease , its importance in day to day computer age. NATIONAL MUSEUM is much bigger, in the foreground is a large oval mirror pond which shows the museum buildings, outside are  well spread gardens with Buddha Statues and a couple of Pagodas, a family picnic park.Museum has an art Gallery on Ground floor presently showing POMPEII Italian ancient city.Other three floors well connected by good elevators to go up and come down show ancient history of mankind and animals, Sections showing history/ culture of India, Japan, China and Korea.Many ceramics, tools, paintings and statues are well preserved and documented..Guides available.A GOOD FEEL OF HISTORY.A good Souvenir shop too.

Definitely lucked out and scored a tour with a super friendly and helpful guide, who kept us all laughing and not getting to bogged down in details. The golden crown is beautiful & there is loads to keep you interested for long after the tour finishes.Also check out the architecture, huge building and very interesting to look at from different angles.

The building itself is very impressive, and there is just SOOO much to see that you need to visit more than once to take it all in. Free English-speaking tours by very good docents are also available and worth your while.

When I went to this museum I honestly did expect a lot of boring displays. But in the end it was really interesting. From the ground floor which has a fast array of early Korean artifacts. To the top floor which has magnificant art and private collections.If you are with friends that enjoy museums you can go through all of it. But for children I would just recommend the ground floor.
Excellent half day tour . Take your time to read Korean history. The facility is clean and full of learning kids that is A + to look around not just the past and also present time.

I always make time to see a couple of museums wherever I go.  This was one of the best of its kind.  Art and history together, everything in context, and beautifully displayed. I know a little about Asian history so I really enjoyed learning more about it. But if you knew nothing, there's plenty to read so you know what you're looking at. The building itself is lovely, and there's a great variety of art and artifacts.
Beautiful location and architecture with ponds.History of Korea is well exposed with many artefactsNice restaurant outside on left of main entrance
This museum has terrific exhibits of historic items, beautifully displayed.  We visited this as part of a field trip for the IMCoS symposium.

If you know nothing about Korea's history, the national museum is a great place to learn a bit about it. I spent around 6 hours there and enjoyed very much this museum, It is very well organized. There is a restaurant there with good food and not so expensive. The outside area is also beautiful, especially during autumn time.
This is a splendid architectural building and the museum's display shows a high degree of expertise. I spent four hours there with not a single tedious moment.

I went early morning of 19th October 2014 to National Korean museum because I wanted to spend a half day there! First of all I found building architecture's beautiful. I liked building outside decoration of garten, plantpots, pool and pavillon. Museum entry is free! Object and exhibited items should be varied and very interesting! But there had been a serious issue with museum male employees who were disturbing me in every hall I entered because they were seeking attention! At each time they walked fast towards my direction while making noises like coughing and that made me nervous! So I couldn't concentrate checking exhibition items! I entered museum at around 09:00 am and almost no visitors were there. I just sow a school class and another visitors group.I unfortunately decided to break off visit and went to check interesting big souvenir shop!

The museum is immense, but it felt like each exhibit was just more and more pots with different labels. Got a bit boring after a while. The Korean history part is somewhat interesting, but the timeline isn't spelled out clearly and the audio guide is pretty bad. It's designed as a dialogue w/ the student often just repeating a question by asking, "Really?". It also doesn't work at all exhibits. Only costs 1000 Won so can't ask for much.

I booked with Seoul city tours and was very dissapointed with their tour. We were told that we only had time for the third pavilion but that was ok because it was the best one.   It was impossible to see anything in 30 minutes.  What I did manage too see was a great reflection on the history of life in Korea. See this on you own so you are not at the whim of a tour

This museum is huge and I had limited time, so I focused on the halls of Buddhist statues and paintings, which were of especial interest to me. Both collections were excellent and contained many rare treasures, including the very famous pensive bodhisattva. I also walked through the celedon ceramics collection, which contained a lot of information on the distinctive Korean artform. I would have liked more time to spend in this massive museum. The gift shop has a very nice collection of souvenirs. If you want cultural and historical background of the Korean people, you should go to the National Folk Museum at Gyeongbokgung Palace. If you want art, come here. But really you should definitely visit both!

A good starting to know Korean Culture. The admission if free, why not have a visit if you have time to do so. The atmosphere of the museum is great, I spent the evening there by just sitting on the park after the visit.
I thought it was strange that this place is free for a museum. Though it gives you a better understanding of the Korean Culture. A definite must visit place when you are in Seoul.

I am not a museum goer but bowed to the pressure of my friend.  I enjoyed the museum both inside and outside - architecturally, it's great!  It has lots of little nooks with vistas of the beautiful landscaping where one can process what one has seen.  The early Korean artifacts are particularly worth the visit.
It is worth numerous visits with free admission. I keep returning since there is so much to see.  An English Auduo guide is available.

The National Museum of Korea is a nice place to visit if you want to understand the Korean history  and culture. It is the 6th largest in the world and the largest in Asia in terms of space. Therefore it entails a lot of walking if you really want to survey the whole area. No need to worry if you get tired, there are lots of sitting areas and drinking fountains strategically placed. It also has a guided tour in the afternoon with English speaking guide. If you want to join the guided tour, be at the lobby before 2pm. The gift shop also has a good selection of souvenir items. Outside, there are other places of interest like the Yongsan Park, Dragon Falls, Pagodas and the like.
It`s an interesting lesson of Korean history. There are also cafes and restaurants and many rest areas.

There you can follow the Korean history from start to almost nowadays. Also they have a really nice collection on eastern art, I was really impressed by a Buda statue from Pakistan/Afganistan border, it had an Helenic style probably because Alexander the Great being in that zone.

I wouldnt have gone here if I wasnt in Seoul for 10 days - if you are here for less I would recommend going to a Temple or another site instead (unless you are REALLY into Korean history) there are 3 floors (which are free to see) and numerous sections with art and collections - I really would recommend this if you are a huge museum and Korean fanaticThere are other exhibits which you must pay for but the general admission was freeThe museum was so crowded! The museum itself and its location was nice

The National Museum of Korea must rank among the best museums I have ever visited. Unlike many national museums that just cram centuries of artifacts into small, poorly illuminated displays, this museum is huge, well organized and most comfortable to get to and walk in. Very near to a metro station, you are wowed even before you enter it. I mean, the main building is massive, and once inside I really appreciated the open, airy space that made me just want to be there all day.The ground floor is for Korean history, and each hall is reserved for a certain period. I thoroughly enjoyed going on this time-machine journey through the centuries and learning about many facets of Korean history unknown to me. There were English information boards and plates everywhere. The English used here is surprisingly perfect. The displays were well spaced and clearly lit. I went to the museum just after it opened so was able to enjoy an hour or so of relative peace before student groups started arriving. I did not have time to explore the upper floors featuring Asian art, but did buy a ticket to the lovely Musee d'Orsay exhibition. I saw the real d'Orsay in Paris but it was good to see some of the works in Seoul as well.I know most tourists hit the palace circuit when in Seoul, but if you have time and perhaps a little bit of interest in how Korea came to be, then you will be rewarded with a truly extraordinary museum once you visit here.

This is an impressive building and collection.however you are only going to enjoy this visit if you have a deep appreciation of korean early history,art,and sculpture.if like me this is not an interest then don't bother.it is some distance from the centre and you must take a taxi.

I wanted to take a break from palaces, temples, and shopping, so I took the subway (Line 4) to Ichon station (use Exit #2 to emerge to street level) and took the short walk - to the end of the block - to the National Museum of Korea. I really enjoyed my time there. It's a beautiful, spacious, bright and modern building. The three floors each have a place to get refreshments just to regroup and reflect from the exquisite pieces (e.g., traditional tea house on the 3rd floor, a cafe on the 2nd, and on the 1st floor, a restaurant on one end and a food court on the other). First floor: Special exhibitions; sculpture and crafts; art from India and Southeast/Central Asia, China, Japan and the Sinan ShipwreckSecond floor: Donated works (some galleries have really impressive collections); calligraphy and paintingsThird floor prehistory and ancient history gallery; medieval and early modern history gallery. Oh, the property also has a children's museum, library, and beautiful gardens.In addition to sign language and Korean, guided tours are offered in English, Japanese and Chinese. The museum also has different gallery talks, etc. I skipped the tour only because I had just come from the adjacent Impressionism exhibit and I wanted to browse the galleries at my own pace. One of the things I loved about this museum is the number of lounges, nooks and alcoves sprinkled throughout the building. Some of them are large with, for example, a expansive view of the garden or outdoor exhibitions below; others are cute little areas off to the side so you can sit and relax; and others are actually small media rooms so you can see short films on some of the works in that particular gallery.Tip: If you're in Seoul through the summer, the museum's Impressionism exhibit from the Musee d'Orsay runs until August 31, 2014. It's 12,000 KRW and audio rental is 3,000 KRW. Since the National Museum itself is free, I didn't mind paying this extra cost for the visiting exhibit. That way, I got to enjoy the museum's permanent collections and also enjoy some pieces from the Musee d'Orsay. Pourquoi pas?

I first visited this place with my school. As schools would, they gave us like 1.5 hours, a worksheet to complete and set us upon the museum like some unfortunate Running Man game without prize, nametags-ripping nor a scary Kim Jongkook. That was not how I wanted to remember this place.I went again with my mum. We took 1 day for each level! As a matter of fact, at this very moment, we have yet to complete Level 1!!! We walked 2 whole days for Levels 2 and 3!This museum has an expansive collection of artifacts both from Korea and from other Asian regions. At the entrance of each section, there are boards to explain the significance of each collection. All artifacts are labelled in Korean, English, Chinese and Japanese. There are also guided tours.However... Please do check for grammatical and spelling errors of the displays. "They go", not "they goes"; "frog" not "flog". Also, 단풍 should be maple, not cherry. The mentioned mistakes were found in the paintings section but I cannot remember which level. My mum's vegetarian and I would like to commend one of the museum staff for recommending us a vegetarian restaurant when he heard about her dietary preference. Also, the restaurant on Level 1, NaMu, was willing to prepare Jeonju Bibimbap without egg. However, they served up banchan with egg rolls and kimchi which contained shrimp paste as ingredients. So do make sure you explain your dietary requirements in detail!This museum is free, allows non-flash photography and has a lot of benches for people to rest at when they are tired. I recommend people to visit this if they have a strong interest in history as well as art. [At the moment, I have not visited the Children's Museum but kids might like that better than this....]

I'm always excited with the prospect of visiting a museum (or any other informal learning institution) for the first time. There is a tingling sense of anticipation when you first see the building from a distance and as you walk up to the lobby, you begin to visualise the wonders to be experienced within. The National Museum of Korea was no different except that the walk to the entrance was so long that by the time I reached the building itself (after being deposited at the main road by bus), I was physically spent.To call the museum sprawling is an understatement. It's a massive footprint and ranks among the top ten largest museums in the world. Just walking from point to point including within the building will take you hours. Though I never expect to 'finish' a museum experience in one visit (or however many since the experience always evolves), the National Museum of Korea is particularly draining although there are some gems in the expansive collection.It's worth noting that the outdoor experience is worth checking out too but I did wished for more leisure friendly facilities like an affordable cafe. There's enough seating and water dispensers but the restaurants I stumbled on were a little pricey (including the premium gift shop). However, I didn't have a chance to fully experience every area so perhaps I may have missed some of the facilities I was looking for.In general, the museum is free to visit but special galleries may have additional charges. There's a children's museum and the main museum consists of significant permanent galleries with changing ones too. It's not too far out from downtown Seoul (took me around 30 minutes by tour bus) and I believe it's also accessible by train (do check the website). The museum is somewhat sterile inside - hushed, not too welcoming, and oh-so serious but well, it is a 'national' museum after all. Even though there are lots I missed in my half day visit, I really wouldn't need to go back.

The National Museum of Korea is extensive in its collection. Ranging from Neolithic Korea all the way to the Joseon dynasty, the museum offers a interesting guide through Korea's rich cultural history. For visitors interested in the Japanese Colonial Period or the Korean War, there are other museums that cover these era's in detail. The national museum focuses on the very ancient to the near modern (late Joseon 1910).Some of the highlights include relics from the Silla, Baekje and Goguryeo dynasties. There is a pummel of a sword from Baekje (7th century AD) that is extremely rare. The royal crown of Silla is also displayed here, the gold and jade is very beautiful. In the main concourse the Ten-Story Pagoda from Gyeongcheonsa Temple (late Goryeo), is astonishing. This national treasure was originally builit in 1348. The pagoda was illegally smuggled to Japan during the colonial period, but luckily was returned through the efforts of the American Homer Hulbert. If you would like to see even more treasures from the Three Kingdoms period specifically, a nice compliment to the National Museum of Korea is the well-known Gyeongju, Buyeo, or Gongu National Museums. As far as I know, there is no specifically designed museum soley for Goryeo relics. All three of the above mentioned museums are worth visiting. To the average visitor pottery is not the most interesting artifact (I know). The national museum has quite a collection, and browsing all of it may be tiring for some. I recommend finding a specific style and focus on that. Korea is famous for Goryeo celadon, which is often gray/green in its color. By the 12th century, the celadon produced in Korea was without equal, with the possible exception of some Song dynasty masterpieces. Advanced techniques of pottery production and kiln design was introduced during the Song dynasty (early Goryeo in Korea). Soon after Korea (Goryeo) was producing an incredible amount of exquisite works. It is also well worth your time to browse and stroll the grounds of the museum, which do hold some interesting statues and ruined sections of ancient structures. The National Museum of Korea is a great introduction into Korean culture and history. The museum is best appreciated after visiting some of Korea's major historical sites. There are comparable exhibits (smaller scale) in some of Korea's other national museums, and in the Tokyo National Museum which houses an enormous collection of Korean artifacts. Enjoy your visit to an excellent museum.

Visited the National Museum of Korea recently and was impressed by the scale of the building and quantity of artifacts within. Entrance to the permanent exhibit is free, while there is a small fee (KRW3000, ~USD2.70) for the special exhibit. Picked up a brochure from the front desk which was good enough for exploring the museum. It has a good layout of the floors, and highlights items of interest (with photos) in selected rooms. Was primarily interested in Korean historical items, and therefore targeted the 1st floor and browsed some rooms on the 3rd floor. The rooms on the 1/F can be chronologically visited starting with the ancient history on the right side, U-turning to medieval/early modern history rooms on the left side. Enjoyed the earlier Kingdoms the most; there was an excellent video in the Goguryeo room, plus found items more visually interesting in this part. Particularly in the Silla room, several artworks were individually encased for better appreciation. The Joseon rooms were a bit dry except for the maps and drawings.The 3rd floor is dedicated to Asian artworks (some are reproductions), Buddhist sculptures and metal works. Thought this floor was memorable for the many bells viewed. At the time of visitation, NMK's special exhibit was on celadon, where an extensive display of this lovely ceramic can be viewed in all forms. Note the last part of the display comprised the "best" of the lot, the celadon artifacts were quite elaborate and very decorative in this segment.Overall, the National Museum of Korea offers a great exhibit of historical domestic (and regional) artifacts which are well worth checking out when traveling to Seoul. This museum has a large cafeteria and extensive outside grounds too which offer a pleasant break from all the viewing. To get to NMK by metro, get off Ichon Station (Line 4) exit #2 and just keep going straight. The walk is about 10-15 minutes. Note the museum is closed on Mondays.
